Posts.Content: Jun 10, 2010 10:39AM PiscesMoon wrote: ebann - thank you for responding :-)  i hope others will chime in to since some of us will be having to take this journey to transfusion land. i went this morning to have my blood type matched.  i went to a radiology place to have it done.  i thought it was odd but they are affiliated with the hospital where i am being transfused so i guess it makes sense.  they just took two vials of blood, gave me one of those hospital bracelet things to wear until after the transfusion, and sent me on my way.  all in all the whole visit took about 15 minutes.  took more time to drive down there.  :-) i'll post tomorrow about how it went and what the procedure was like etc.  maybe someone will read this thread and get some comfort from it.  it feels kind of weird thinking that i'll have someone else's blood in me.  it brings home the importance of donating blood.  i'll have to put a big thank you out there for whoever did it.  :-) ~M
Posts.Title: blood transfusion scheduled for friday PiscesMoon PiscesMoon

Posts.Content: Jun 13, 2010 12:32AM PiscesMoon wrote: well i was given two units.  took about 2 hours or so for each unit.  and the infusion room was as cold in the hospital as it is in my cancer center i go to.  only different thing was that they fed us lunch during our infusions from the hospital menu.  quite yummy - i had a veggie burger and fries.  it was a full menu, breakfast, lunch, dinner.  the cancer centers should do that too. lol  then i had to get wheeled out cuz i was patient.  i hate wheelchairs coming out of the hospital like that.  but maybe that's just me.  i didnt have any reactions.  napped a bit from the benedryl but that was it. ~M
Posts.Title: blood transfusion scheduled for friday PiscesMoon PiscesMoon

Posts.Content: PiscesMoon wrote: friday i'm going to get transfused.  hemoglobin is low and i'm having shortness of breath and pounding heart when i excert myself like say just walking around.   i've never had a blood transfusion before.  it's going to be done at a local hospital that has an infusion center.  apparently they'll be able to access my power port for the procedure. if you've been through blood transfusions can you tell your experiences, what to expect, reactions, etc.?  i know they are are going to give me tylonal and benedryl so i think i'm pretty much going to nap through this but any feedback would be greatfully appreciated.  ~M DX: 11/13/09; IDC, 3.5 cm, Stage 2, Grade 2, 0/2 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2+++ ~mellow greetings, citizen...what seems to be your boggle?~ Log in to post a reply

Posts.Title: Should I Postpone? Julia257 Julia257

Posts.Content: May 27, 2010 12:50AM PiscesMoon wrote: jeanwash good luck on your surgery!  i, too had a uni mx (left breast only removed).  i had DCIS and IDC in my breast; for whatever reason they concentrate only on the IDC.  at any rate i can tell that you are heading into this full of fire and i think that's great!  you can always get reconstruction later if that is what you choose.  i chose no recon (didn't want more surgery and recovery time) but everyone is different and it's an extremely personal choice.  it sounds like you are surrounding yourself with a great support group, family and friends.  that is imperitive to have at this time in your life.  if you do have to do chemo and don't want to tell anyone at work that's fine.  sometimes, though, it does help to share with them.  the people i work with are fantastic and very supportive and caring. good eating and excercise is always great for anyone.  but i don't think that it's just diet or lack thereof that causes us to get this to begin with.  i have no family history either and am 43 years old.  i was never a real health nut. the state i live in has the bad luck of having breast cancer as the number one cancer of women who live here.  but i believe it has to be the perfect storm for us to get this unwanted visitor, breast cancer.  for me it's a waste of energy to worry about if i gave this to myself and is counterproductive to my own recovery.  it is what it is.  this is what we have to go through right now.  is it fair?  nope.  will we get through it?  yup. use this website as your support and your base for knowledge.  there are so many fantastic women here that can help you through this challenge in your life.  i hope you have found the surgery forum on this website.  there is a lot of good information there on recovery. i wish you a fast recovery and good results on your pathology report. ~M

Posts.Title: onco or breast surgeon..which visit first? PiscesMoon MaineCoonKitty

Posts.Content: Dec 13, 2009 05:43PM PiscesMoon wrote: just thought i'd give you an update.  my onco visit went well.  he didn't tell me anything surprising - since i've been researching and learning everything i can since my dx (11/13/09).  i asked him about putting off surgery until after the holidays - he agreed it would be okay but not to go beyond that.  he also told me that they treat the her2+++ as node positive even if the nodes are not involved.  he said most likely 3 months of chemo and 1 year of herceptin.  of course surgery will give us a good and final picture of what treatment will be.

Posts.Title: needing an extraction before chemo PiscesMoon JulieC

Posts.Content: Feb 21, 2010 04:26PM PiscesMoon wrote: my surgeon was pushing lumpectomy for me and i chose mx.  my reasoning (for me) was that i did not want to have a high maintance breast.  i also had a complex cyst in that breast.  i have very dense breasts that are hard to read on mammo's and u/s's.  the lumpectomy would cause scar tissue and i didn't want to have to worry about battling a radiologist who would be 'biopsy happy' when seeing scar tissue.  also, my cancer is HER+++ and i did not want to have rads in addition to chemo.  i chose not to have recon.  i've never been in love with my breasts.  they were never perky pretty things.  maybe i would have thought differently if they had been.  i am happy that i chose a mx.  my tumor turned out to be 3.5 cm instead of the 2.3 that the other tests showed so i'm guessing that when they would have done the lumpectomy they wouldn't have gotten clean margins.  it is such a personal choice for a woman to make.  i have no regrets at all.  you just have to make the choice you are most comfortable with - whether or not the docs deem it 'medically necessary'.  after all, it is your body, not theirs. good luck to you!  :-) ~M

Posts.Content: Oct 17, 2012 10:41AM PiscesMoon wrote: hi frapp :-)  i'm a 42DD and had a UMX with no recon and i wear no foob.  it's weird that my stomach looks like it sticks out on the one side.  i'm a larger person so people really don't notice (or say anything) when i go around 'one-sided' lol.  i made the decision a long time ago that going around with one breast doesn't bother me and if it bothers others than that's their problem.  i guess that sounds a little harsh but i've been so harsh on my self-judgement on my own body and after bc i learned to mostly accept the way that my body is.  it is what it is.  i didn't even wear scarves or a wig when i was bald.  it's a very personal decision but i think it helps to try and learn to not care too much what others think.  :-) ~M

Posts.Content: May 22, 2010 09:09PM PiscesMoon wrote: hi judy i didn't have a lumpectomy but a mastectomy and i can relate to the sloshing sound.  lol  i had my surgery in feb and have had to go back every two or three weeks since my drains were removed to have the fluid asperated.  it doesn't hurt or anything but i tell them all the time when i call that i have a waterbed on my chest. ;-)  i guess it's different with a lumpetcomy in that the surgeon will allow the fluid to be absorbed?  anyway i wish you luck in your recovery! ~M

Posts.Content: Dec 8, 2009 07:36PM PiscesMoon wrote: thanks for everyone replying.  the meeting with the onc went great.  i really like him.  he did confirm that because of my her2+++ status (pending a SISH test) the treatment would be 3 months of chemo and 1 year herceptin.  he recommended several good breast surgeons i will be looking into.  i am going to a cancer center and the facilities are awesome.  they do both chemo and radiation there.  they have a 'financial counselor' and social worker etc on site.  now just have to wait for final path after surgery to confirm what road to take next.
